Field studies had found that strippers who were ovulating got substantially better tips than other strippers at the same time, or themselves when not ovulating. That is not an ironclad proof, but it is interesting.

As highly social species, advanced hominids needed to avoid internecine conflict threatening group cohesion. An excited VNO short-circuits other patterns of behavior, and takes over. Humans can have diverted pheromone response to be redirected through a filter in the brain which signaled not to bting ruin down onto your group just because you were horny.

Babies smell nice (when they don’t have a full diaper) I have noticed that fear has a smell. I take care of animals and have noticed it. Also people. ...I have almost no sense of smell. I remember almost nothing of my childhood before age 10.

Recently I became aware of the concept of the "smell of fear". Sweat, stress, subtle chemical signatures etc, all these things might be released when a creature feels fear, and predators are hardwired and driven to chase after prey.
So I wonder if the smell of "fear" is also somewhat appetizing to predators. For many animals with highly attuned sense of smells, they might familiarize with the smell, and thus make the association with it to food.

Also the smell of "distress" I bet is another thing that exists, probably very similar to fear. More sweat, but also accompanied by more details, such as potential injury.

I don't even want to imagine how a sick or injured baby animal smells like - have you seen how adults take a sniff, and then physically react when they reject the cub? As in they like, snort or sniff, shake their heads, like they smelled something bad or startling or alarming.

The world of smell is something I would like to experience someday. Imagine being able to smell as well as a bear, whom have seven times the smell power of bloodhounds. Imagine being able to smell another person and instantly know what they eat on a regular basis, if they are ill in some noticeable way (imagine if most STD's actually had a vague smell?), if they use die, what kind of makeup products they use, etc.
Imagine the landscape of soaps and perfumes!! Honestly, its a fun concept to think about because we can easily forget just how important sense of smell is.

I love the smell of babies. I've had 4 children from the ages of 42, 38, and 2 younger children ages 26 and 27 and had them I'm my later years and yes, I completely agree. What I know for a fact that even smelling their scalps, and you/women fall In love right away and that's because of the endorphins and oxytocin especially when you have a completely natural birth, not as much with my last baby who was a high risk pregnancy because I was literally perforated in my uterus, because the medical protocol was not breaking my water, which my midwife from my first to, broke my water and I never had a problem,, however I went to New England Medical Center on Boston, Massachusetts in a brand new maternity ward.  Turns out that they saw my son , second youngest, and myself had a full 3 day forced labor 😐😑😒and it was the most horrible experience.  As a matter of fact, for the women out there, don't let them use pertossin.. it's very bad for you and your baby, trying to summarize this,  needless to say they tried to turn my baby from the outside of my body, thus ending up perforating my uterus and I screamed, give me a saddle block right away I'm pushing my baby out right now 😢and they argued the point and said c-section 💔no way. To make a long story short, I was perforated and hemorrhaging and still breastfed, that made me bleed further. 💔 I walked around for several days after, and I ended up being rushed to the same hospital and they were shocked and scratching their heads. comment_text: Now there are groups of people that deny science and say the concept of woman is constructed.... Explain that to a scientist who study the biological effects of babies on women....

One thing about our "lack of smell ability" could also be we don't "train" it as often as our other senses , if you think about it we mostly try to visually ID things or register them audibly , we more often hear or see something wrong first , unless the smell is something we immediately ID as dangerous or simply FOUL like smoke or something rotting or egg farts . As an example,  I've worked security for years , mostly in nightclubs, and despite likely having hearing damage from the loud music I will catch someone talking and immediately react to the "tone of voice" over any words I actually decipher or I'll scan a crowd and spot one guy in a particular "body stance" and begin preparing myself to act , but unless someone has some really strong odor either from cologne perfume or BO I don't notice it

I've always said babies smell wonderful, yet had moms tell me it was just spoiled milk!?!? It's their heads. Their heads smell like some sort of flower. I'm an uncle and great uncle a dozen times over. I know I'm not smelling spoiled milk. Their smell makes me want to cuddle them, and protect them, and wistfully wish I had been a father.

For childhood memories, I recall Georgia pines, and some sort of odor that was in the fog of Warner Robbins, GA, early 1970s, that reminded me of ham. No idea what that was. Old books smell a bit like vanilla, which is a component of all of my favourite colognes, including Coty's "Raw Vanilla," and Polo "Green," which also has two of my other favourite scents, lime oil, and cedar oil. Genuine rose oil is also a favourite. Meanwhile, I can't smell musk. Musk colognes, along with carnations, just smell like plastic to me. Strangely, because of a vinyl-coated crib bumper pad, the smell of vinyl relaxes me, making me want to sleep.

As for the smell of sweat, women's sweat makes me want to vomit, and my dad's was just gross, but other men's is extremely attracting. I'm not talking like unwashed homeless cumin sweat. That's gross. I'm talking gym workout with having showered that morning sweat. Men who wash that off or cover that up are less attractive. It's best when mixed with some of the other favourite odors. Work sweat with cedar, lime, and vanilla, is perfect. Meanwhile, thankfully, as someone getting older, I have an Asian allele that cause my sebaceous secretions to have less oil, so I should have less Nonenal. Yay? Meanwhile again, can someone do something about Cystic Fibrosis carrier breath?

I notice people’s home smells! People who live together have similar smells, though it’s still a bit different from person to person. It passes onto their rooms, their cars, and their clothes. And it changes with the introduction of a new pet or new person, or when the people move houses.
I have memories attached to specific home smells, because I spent so much time with those people and in those houses. But I wouldn’t say home smells are inherently good or bad smells, they’re just kind of indescribably complex.

Filipinos will simultaneously smell and kiss someone they love on the arm. Typically it’s a baby or some younger relative. It’s like sniff-kiss-sniff-kiss coddling. I’m second generation and just half so I don’t know all about it but it’s definitely a thing lol.

I def. think that looking into how newborn babies react to certain scents/how humans react to the smell of babies would be a good way of detecting any pheromones we might have, because we're such an absurdly parental and social species that it would be advantageous for our children (who are a drag to care for, to put it mildly) to have pheromone cues that elicit that reaction in other humans even if they're not related to them. Also, while it's likely not a pheromone cue at all, that distinct smell of sickness that people get regardless of what illness they have might be interesting to do further research on in the future
all very nice, but unfortunately babies smell awful.

I don't really see the point of even trying to find human pheromones. We are constantly washing our skin; washing these pheromones away or smothering them with the unnatural scents of cleansers, moisturisers, perfumes, deodorants, etc. Our clothes could act as a physical barrier as well as a smothering barrier due to the scent of our laundry detergent. What you guys want is an honest cave-man (and/or woman!), but your so-called civilised noses wouldn't let you near them!

The main reason for not having analized pheromones is because their "aromatic-off gassing" time-period is kinda short, it's meant for a response from the sniffer to the sender. There are scents that do entice a specific response, w/o it being tied to a specific type of memory, it's just a reaction.  Like a 20° temperature drop and the human-thermometer area of the chest shows it 😁, reactional type of response, so there are pheromones within humans that work based on primal instincts.
